Award.AwardTitle: SHF: CSR: Small: Toward Smart HPC through Active Learning and Intelligent Scheduling

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
As high performance computing (HPC) continues to grow in scale, energy and resilience become first-class concerns, in addition to the pursuit of performance. These concerns demand significant changes in many aspects of the system stack including resource management and job scheduling. In order to harness the great potential of extreme scale systems, this project aims to incorporate intelligence into resource management and job scheduling. More specifically, it will develop a framework named SPEaR (Scheduling for Performance, Energy, and Resilience efficiency) for dynamically optimizing the three-dimensional performance, energy, and resilience scheduling. The research focuses on two thrusts: one is active learning to automatically extract valuable performance, energy, and resilience patterns and tradeoffs out of application and system data, and the other is intelligent scheduling to improve and control performance, resilience, and energy efficiency in resource management and scheduling. An event-driven scheduling simulator is being developed for comprehensively evaluating scheduling policies and their aggregate effects. The simulator, along with system logs, will be made available to the broad community under an open source license.
This project creates critical technologies to promote system productivity and makes important advances essential toward smart HPC. Additionally, the learning techniques developed in this project are useful to other big data problems of national interests. The education plan enhances the undergraduate and graduate curricula and broadens the participation from underrepresented groups.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Being analogous to smart grids, this project aims to develop critical technologies toward smart HPC (high-performance computing) in which information about resources and applications will be automatically gathered, analyzed, and acted on for improving performance, resilience, and energy efficiency. The project developed a framework named SPEaR (Scheduling for Performance, Energy, and Resilience efficiency). SPEaR provides the necessary foundation from which further resource management and job scheduling enhancements can be developed to meet the rapidly expanding needs of diverse HPC workloads and hence accelerates the pace of discovery and innovation across a broad range of scientific disciplines.

The project has two key outcomes. One is active learning to automatically extract actionable performance, energy, and resilience knowledge, and the other is intelligent scheduling to adapt job allocation to workload requirement and resource change.  The active learning work not only advances knowledge discovery for translating massive data into valuable insights, but also provides a deeper understanding of performance, energy, and resilience tradeoffs on extreme scale systems. The intelligent scheduling work goes well beyond the existing CPU-centric scheduling approach to a flexible scheduling design that adaptively manages a variety of on-chip and off-chip resources in an integrated and optimized way.

SPEaR is the first systematic approach to addressing significant challenges toward smart HPC. It has a direct impact on system productivity as well as a broad range of scientific domains that use supercomputers for simulation and data analysis. Moreover, the learning techniques developed in this project may be proven useful to other big data problems of national interests.

This project published over twenty technical papers at premier conferences and journals, as well as four doctoral dissertations. The resulting software artifacts include an event-driven scheduling simulator CQSim, an enhanced networking simulation toolkit CODES, and a number of workload traces collected from production systems.  The software artifacts and the data are all freely available to the community.

Another key outcome was the training of a group of students, ranging from undergraduate students to doctoral students, in the field of high-performance computing. The PI was dedicated to enhancing diversity in computing. Among the participating students, five are from underrepresented groups (four female and one Hispanic).

The use of robotics is an effective strategy to promote computing to pre-college students. FIRST (https://www.firstinspires.org/), a not-for profit public charity, organizes various robotics programs for pre-college students. The PI engaged in several outreach programs for K-12 students including serving as lead coach for the FIRST Lego League team at a local elementary school and providing field inspection at several FIRST Tech Challenge competitions in the Greater Chicago area.
